articles.title: HDAT9800 Chapter 1
articles.description: Chapter 1 material for HDAT9800 Visualisation & Communication of Health Data
articles.contents:
Contents
What’s in the lectures and tutorials for this Chapter?
Pre-recorded lectures for Chapter 1
Tutorials for Chapter 1
Introduction to R Tutorials for Beginners
Who should complete the Introduction to R modules?


Interactive sessions for Chapter 1
Chapter 1 assessment exercise




Graphic by Alison Horst, used under CC-BY license.
What’s in the lectures and tutorials for this Chapter?
This chapter provides a course overview, including course aims and principles, as well as a brief review of the history of data visualisation (Chapter 1 - Course Overview - Part 1). It also provides an introduction to the core curriculum material for each of the chapter topics including an introduction to R, dplyr, literate programming, git, ggplot2, collaborating with git, using leaflet for mapping, using shiny for interactive applications, and the shiny group project (Chapter 1 - Course Overview - Part 2).
There is also an introduction to using git for version control (Chapter 1 - Version control with git and GitHub - Part 1), and how to set up and configure git with RStudio, how to access the assessment repository and the chapter 1 assessment (Chapter 1 - Version control with git and GitHub - Part 2).
View the lecture videos, and download the lecture notes if you want to follow along with the presenter (or for revision later).
After you have viewed the lectures, please proceed to do the learnr tutorials on git.
There is also an interactive learnr tutorial covering data manipulation using dplyr in R. This is also foundational material for later chapters, which will require the use of dplyr and related packages to manipulate and shape data for visualation and reporting.
The interactive tutorial session for Chapter 1 will start with a get-to-know-you session, in which we each introduce ourselves, and talk about our favourite data visualisation or chart (see below). There will be an opportunity for questions and answers (Q&A) about the core course material, and then a hands-on session in which we use the dplyr package in R to access and manipulate data in databases, along with a discussion of some fundamental concepts of computer architecture and operations which are important to understand when working with “big data”.
Links and further instructions for each component are provided in the sections below.
Pre-recorded lectures for Chapter 1
View the lecture videos below, and download the lecture notes if you want to follow along with the presenter (or for revision later).
After you have viewed the lectures, please proceed to do the related git tutorials (see below).
Course overview including course aims and principles (Chapter 1 - Course Overview - Part 1)







Introduction of chapter topics including R, dplyr, literate programming, git, ggplot2, collaborating with git, leaflet, shiny and the shiny group project (Chapter 1 - Course Overview - Part 2)







Slide deck for Chapter 1 - Course Overview - Parst 1 & 2
Using git for version control (Chapter 1 - Version control with git and GitHub - Part 1)







Setting up and configuring git, setting up git with RStudio, how to access the assessment repository and the chapter 1 assessment (Chapter 1 - Version control with git and GitHub - Part 2)







Slide deck for Chapter 1 - git and GitHub - Parts 1 & 2
Tutorials for Chapter 1
Every chapter includes one or more interactive tutorials/practicals, which consists of introductory concepts, readings and exercises, generally provided as an R package of learnr tutorials. learnr is a package which allows interactive tutorials about R (or related topics) to be written in R.
You should download and install the cbdrhintro tutorials package for R by following the instructions provided on the home page. Intructions for installing R and RStudio are provided [here][installing_r.html).
The Chapter 1 tutorials have three parts:
Introduction to R tutorials (proficient R users can quickly run through or skip these tutorials, see the more detailed description of these tutorials below)
Introduction to git and GitHub
Introduction to dplyr
Please work through the content in the tutorials after you have watched the prerecorded lecture for this chapter.
If you have any questions about the tutorials, or if you want to share any useful resources or post insights, please post in the Teams space for the course, in the channel for Chapter 1.
Introduction to R Tutorials for Beginners
R is fast becoming the industry standard programming language for statistical data analysis. If this is your first exposure to R, we have created some beginner R modules to introduce you to the R language and to help you build some basic programming skills.
The modules are delivered as 6 learnr tutorials as a R package called cbdrhintro. Each module consists of explanatory text and coding examples. The tutorials are interactive so you can write and run code to see how it works, then check your code against the provided solutions. The coding tasks in these tutorial modules are not marked assessments, so don’t worry if you make mistakes. Each module is organised into several subtopics, which are bookmarked making it easy to pause and return at a later time.
Module 1: Introduction to R, variable types and operators
Module 2: Vectors
Module 3: Matrices, matrix arithmetic and lists
Module 4: Data frames and Factors
Module 5: Functions
Module 6: Control structures and control-like structures
Who should complete the Introduction to R modules?
R programming is a major component of many of the UNSW Health Data Science courses. Some of the R dependent courses will include these same learnr tutorials as part of the course content. If you have already worked through them, there is no need to do them again (unless you wish to for revision purposes). However if you are completely new to programming or new to R, we recommend spending some time reviewing and practising the lessons of these modules during the first few weeks of the HDAT9800 course.
For some students, this will be a lot of material to cover. Don’t panic! The course (and the assessment due dates) are paced so that there is plenty of time to get to grips with the fundamentals of R programming. If you would like additional interactive tutorials covering the Introduction to R material or the opportunity to ask questions about it individually or in small groups, please let me know on Teams or at timothy.churches@unsw.edu.au.
Please follow the instructions for installing the cbdrhintro tutorials package for R on the course home page and proceed to do the dplyr tutorial. We will revisit and revise the use of dply in the interactive session, and examine how it can be used to access “big data” contained in databases, in the context of modern computing architecture and operation.
If you are unfamiliar with R, you should also work through the six introduction to R tutorials that are also contained in and installed by that package.
Interactive sessions for Chapter 1

Note:
Chapter 1 assessment exercise
For chapter 1, the assessment exercise is very easy, and is designed to get you used to completing assessments using git and GitHub.
Make sure you have installed git on your computer and that you have a GitHub account, as explained in the pre-recorded lectures and tutorials on git (see above), and that git is configured in RStudio.
Then you can click on this link to the Chapter 1 assessment GitHub Classroom repository: https://classroom.github.com/a/4J9wKhgK
This will create a new GitHub repository for you, just for this assignment. Only you and the course instructors can access it, it is not public.
You should then clone this assignemnt repository to your local computer, using RStudio (or other git interfaces such as GitHub Desktop if you prefer). Complete the assignment (assessment task) according to the instructions given, save and commit your work to your local git repository, and then push that work back to the remote GitHub repository for the assessment (this should all be automatically set up when you clone the repo in RStudio).
You may revise you assessment task(s) as many times as you wish. We will mark the last committed version that you push to the GitHub repository for your chapter assessment by the due date.
Procedures for requesting early marking of your assignement (before the due date) will appear here shortly.

Errors or omissions on this website

articles.title: HDAT9800 Health Data Visualisation and Communication
articles.description:
The greatest value of a picture is when it forces us to notice what we never expected to see.
-- John Tukey
articles.contents:
Contents
About the HDAT9800 course
Course Schedule Term 2 2022
Teams Space
Weekly interactive tutorials
The tutorials R packages
Assessments
Weekly core curriculum assessments
Additional assessments
Group assessment
Assessment exercises timetable

Readings and resources




About the HDAT9800 course
Health Data Scientists need to present information to audiences across a range of backgrounds and spanning a spectrum from naïve or non-practitioners of a discipline to highly informed and expert audiences. Effective communication across different media types is essential. Appropriate data visualisation techniques can greatly enhance communication and increase the effectiveness of communication. Data visualisation is an essential part of every data analysis. Increasingly the scientific community has become aware of problems regarding lack of transparency and reproducibility, and the use of fully reproducible methods of working are now essential.
This course takes a toolbox approach to creating appropriate, reproducible and transparent analyses and visualisations, and communicating them via various channels and modes, including informal and formal written communication, online communication and via interactive applications. In the context of R, it presents useful best-practice data science analysis and visualisation techniques with a focus on different types of data visualisations.
This course was originally developed in 2018 by Dr James Farrow and Dr Tim Churches. It was co-presented by James and Tim in 2018 and 2019, and co-presented by James and Tim in entirely online form in 2020, and by Tim and Andy Blance in 2021. Although the core material for the course remains substantially unchanged, a great deal of additional material was added in 2021, and for 2022 some further topics will be covered.
The original course introduction recorded by Dr James Farrow appears below, and is still valid - we have not removed anything from the core curriculum, although quite a lot of the material has been updated or supplemented to reflect recent developments. The additional material added in 2021 and 2022 will be covered in the interactive sessions on Thursday afternoons/evenings in the Term 2 2022 running of the course.







Course Schedule Term 2 2022

Links to slides and recordings will be posted on the page for each (weekly) chapter throughout the course.
For Term 2 2022, the course is provided in both blended (hydrid) and online formats. Each Chapter, which corresponds to a week in the ten week course, comprises pre-recorded lectures, interactive tutorials which student work through themselves, and a weekly interactive tutorial session. These tutorial sessions are provided in both online and face-to-face form (on teh UNSW Kensington campus).
There is a web page for each chapter (week) of the course, setting out exactly what you need to do each week (see links in the Course Schedule table below).


Week


Week starting


Core topic(s)


Additional topic(s)


Online Tutorial


Face-to-Face Tutorial


Chapter web page


Tutorial recordings


Week 1


Mon 30 May


Course Introduction; What is Data Visualisation; Introduction to R; Introduction to git


Introductions; dplyr and the R tidyverse; computer architecture, databases, SQL and accessing databases from R; hands-on exercise


6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 1 Jun


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 2 Jun








Week 2


Mon 06 June


Introduction to Literate Programming


Presentations by program code; communication by self-publishing; hands-on setting up your own health data science blog; a visualisation I am proud of (guest presentation)


6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 8 Jun


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 9 Jun








Week 3


Mon 13 June


Constructing Charts using ggplot


Some more visualisation theory; more on data visualisation using ggplot2


6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 15 Jun


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 16 Jun








Week 4


Mon 20 June


Collaborative Report Writing (including tables)


Visualisation with Python – guest tutorial by Dr Georgina Kennedy


6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 22 Jun


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 23 Jun








Week 5


Mon 27 June


Visualisation and Mapping part 1


Theories of Visual Perception – guest tutorial by Andy Blance; a visualisation I am proud of (guest presentation)


6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 29 Jun


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 30 Jun








Week 6


Mon 04 July


Building Interactive Data-driven Web Apps using Shiny part 1


Visualisation and exploratory data analysis; visualisation of statistical models


6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 6 Jul


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 7 Jul








Week 7


Mon 11 July


Visualisation and Mapping part 2


Incorporating time – uses and misuses of animation in data visualisation; accessibility aspects of visualisation


6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 13 Jul


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 14 Jul








Week 8


Mon 18 July


Building Interactive Data-driven Web Apps using Shiny part 2


Visualisation of categorical data; visualising big data; a visualisation I am proud of (guest presentation)


6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 20 Jul


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 21 Jul








Week 9


Mon 25 July


Building Interactive Data-driven Web Apps using Shiny part 3


Communicating COVID-19 models through Markdown documents, web sites, pre-print papers and Shiny apps – guest presentation by Dr Mark Hanly


6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 27 Jul


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 28 Jul








Week 10


Mon 01 August


Course Review and Group Project Presentations


Visualising higher dimensions – uses and misuses of 3D graphics; dimensionality reduction techniques, including guest presentation by Dr Meg Stevens on visualising NLP models


6:00pm-8:30pm (online), Wed 3 Aug


2:00pm-4:30pm (F2F), Thur 4 Aug









Teams Space
Discussions, questions and online tutorials will be hosted in the course Teams Space which you can access here.

Weekly interactive tutorials
A weekly interactive tutorial session is offered, in both online and face-to-face formats. The material covered in both formats is identical. Each tutorial starts with a question-and-answer sessions on teh core curriculum material for that and previous weeks, and then goes on to cover additional material, usually a mixture of short lectures or presentations and a hands-on practical exercise. Some weeks feature a guest presenter (see details in the course schedule table below and on each course chapter page).
Attendance at tutorial sessions is optional but strongly encouraged. However, we recognise that some students may not be able to attend either the online or the face-to-face sessions due to work, family or other commitments. For those students, the online sessions will be recorded and available the next day for viewing at their convenience.
The online interactive tutorials will be held using Teams at 6pm (Sydney time) each Wednesday. The tutorial will usually last between 2 and 2.5 hours. You can join the tutorials using this link. These tutorials should also appear in your Teams calendar.
The face-to-face interactive tutorials will be held on the UNSW Kensingtom campus in the Mathews 104 room (K-F23-104) starting at 2pm each Thursday. These tutorials will also usually last between 2 and 2.5 hours. It may not be possible for all guest presenters to attend these tutorials in person, in which case the presentations may be provided online or students may view the recorded online tutorial for those parts of the tutorial. Please bring your laptop to these tutorials.
The tutorials R packages
Online, hosted versions of the learnr tutorials for this course can be accessed through the links in the Course Schedule table above, but it is better to use a local copy that you can work on in the RStudio environment without the need for internet access. You will need a copy of R and RStudio running on your computer in order to participate in the interactive (face-to-face or online) tutorial sessions held each Thursday, and to complete and submit assignments.
If you do not already have R and RStudio installed, please follow the instructions on the Installing R page. If you have any problems or questions please contact the course convenor Tim Churches on teams of by email at timothy.churches@unsw.edu.au.
Once installed, the tutorials can be accessed via the Tutorial tab in the upper right-hand pane of the RStudio application window.
The tutorials for Chapter 1 are shipped in the package cbdrhintro. To install this package you can enter the following code at the console:


devtools::install_github("CBDRH/cbdrhintro")



You may get prompted to update some packages. You can chose to ignore this by selecting option 3 (None).

If you choose to update packages, you may subsequently be asked if you want to install binary or source versions. Source versions require special tools to compile which you may not have configured, so you should choose to install the binary version, i.e. if prompted Do you want to install from sources the packages which need compilation? enter n for ‘No’.
The package installation can occasionally fail, usually if there is a dependency that is not installed or has an outdated version. If you get an error message relating to a package, try installing that package first and then try again. If there are still issues, don’t worry, just drop an email to the course convenor.
Please note: if you have installed the cbdrhintro previously, you will need to re-install it again because we have added a tutorial for dplyr required for Chapter 1 of this course.
Instructions for installing the R tutorials package for Chapter 2 to 9 of the HDAT9800 course will appear here in the near future.

Back to the top 

Assessments
Weekly core curriculum assessments
There are weekly individual assessments for Chapters 1 to 7. Each of these assessments is worth 8% of the total marks for the course, thus 56% all together. These weekly assessments cover the core course material and should be fairly easy and will not take very long to complete if you have worked through the core curriculum material. The weekly assessments must be submitted for marking no later than three weeks after the opening date for the chapter they relate to – the exact dates for each are shown in the table below. However, you are encouraged to submit the core curriculum assignments early, if possible, to allow more time for the additional assignments (see below). The course instructors will endeavour to mark and return assignments submitted before the due date as quickly as possible, so that you can get feedback and assurance on your progress and understanding of the course material.
Additional assessments
There are also two additional assignments. These relate to topics covered in the Thursday tutorial sessions, but require additional independent research and some creativity to complete. Each is worth 7% of the total course marks, thus 14% all together. The exact dates on which each these are due is also shown in the table below. These assignments will be marked promptly after the due date for each.

In the 2021 running of this course we set these additional assessment tasks every week. However, feedback from students was that the assessment burden was too great and that they didn’t have time to do the additional assessments justice. Therefore we have reduced the number of these additional assessments to just two this year.
Group assessment
In week 6 of the course, you will be asked to form into small groups of 3 or 4 students each, to undertake a group assessment task. More details of this task will be provided in week 4 of the course. Each group will be required to present their group project in the Thursday sessions in week 10, and then submit all the code for the project in the week following that. The group assessment is worth 30% of the overall course marks.
Assessment exercises timetable

Click the link to clone a personal copy of the GitHub repo for each assessment. You will complete your assessment as an RMarkdown document, pushing it back to GitHub when you are ready to submit.

Readings and resources
There are links to readings and additional resources on the page for each chapter of the course. You should prioritise the core readings each week.

articles.title: Installing R and RStudio
articles.description: Instructions for installing R and RStudio on your computer
articles.contents:
To participate in the HDAT9800 course you will need a copy of both R and RStudio installed on your computer. Both R and RStudio are free, open-source software available at no cost and able to be installed on as many computers as you wish at no charge.
R is a programming language and associated software libraries designed for statistical and data science computing. It is the “engine”, but provides only simple user interfaces. RStudio is an IDE (integrated development environment) application designed specifically for R although it works with other programming languages such as Python. It provides a very convenient and easy-to-use interface for working with R.
First download R (choose the installation package appropriate for your computer’s operating system - Win/MacOS/Linux) from CRAN (the Comprehensive R Archive Network, which distributes R software worldwide via a series of mirror sites) at https://cloud.r-project.org. Download the R package appropriate for your computer’s operating system (Windows, Apple macOS or Linux) from the “Download and Install R” section at the top of the CRAN distribution page. Locate the downloaded package file in your downloads directory, and open it to run it. Just use the default settings for the installation.
Next, download RStudio Desktop from https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/. Select the free Open Source Edition. It should take you to this page. Download the package appropriate for your computer’s operating system (it should detect that and offer the correct package next to step 2. on the Rstudio downlaod page at https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/#download. Locate the downloaded file in your Downloads folder, open it to initiate the RStudio installation wizard.Again, just follow the installation default options offered.
Open RStudio - when it opens it should automatically detect and link to the R installation on your computer.
You can learn more about what’s available in RStudio Desktop here: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/#Desktop
You will also need to install and configure git on your computer. This is covered in the tutorials on git and GitHub available on the Chapter 1 page for the HDAT9800 course.
